sub_title: Assistant Professor @ University of Amsterdam | Research Fellow @ Amsterdam Institute for Global Health and Development | PhD in Social Anthropology from University of Cambridge
summary: I am a social anthropologist trained at the University of Cambridge, teaching and researching at the University of Amsterdam. I am an expert on people with intellectual disabilities in different cultural settings which has enabled me to pioneer the anthropological study of the condition. I run three long-term qualitative research projects on the way support networks affect resilience for people with intellectual disabilities – including the first long-term ethnographic project with these individuals in India, looking at family and community responses. I teach on the social science of health, psychology, religion, care, and ethics. I am transitioning to working in Global Mental Health, and I am currently investigating which roles would suit me best. I intend to contribute to addressing the mental health care gap in the Global South, and in particular to developing culturally-adapted care systems for people with intellectual disabilities in LMIC.

projects.title: Research Design in Medical Anthropology
projects.description: I co-teach this course on the Masters in Medical Anthropology and Sociology with Dr Else Vogel, an expert in medical anthropology. Together, we train a cohort of 20+ students to write a research proposal for high level masters research in a topic of their choosing in global health. This involves training students to develop coherent and intelligent research designs, adhere to ethical standards, manage data correctly, and write compelling proposals for research.

projects.title: Beyond Belief: Understanding Religious Thought and Practice
projects.description:
As an expert in the anthropology of religion, I designed from scratch this 60-hour course for final-year undergraduates in social anthropology to teach them how to understand religious thought and behaviour, culminating in a 6,000 word paper on an empirical case of their choosing. I run all aspects of the course: design, management, teaching, grading, and evaluation. The course has been consistently highly evaluated by students each of the times I have taught it.

The course starts from popular explanations of why religious people are supposedly mistaken: they are uneducated, they have no way to question the ideas their culture has given them, they are controlled by ruling elites, they are confusing hope with reality etc. But what if religious people are not mistaken in their thought and action? Over 4-months, the course teaches students anthropological tools to challenge this way of thinking, and the colonial and authoritarian assumptions embedded in these seemingly scientific explanations. It teaches students the research and writing skills to construct richer interpretations that make meaningful sense of religious thought and action.

projects.title: Contemporary Debates: Health
projects.description:
As a medical anthropologist, I designed this 60-hour course for second-year undergraduates in social science to teach them how to think about and research health from a social-scientific perspective. I run all aspects of the course: design, management, teaching, grading, and evaluation. The course has been consistently highly evaluated by students each of the times I have taught it. 

Over 4 months, the course introduces students to the central topics in the social science of health - showing them how to use research in political science, geography, sociology, and anthropology to think about health beyond biology alone. I teach students the major theoretical tools in lectures, and also organise guest lectures from different faculties as well as from NGOs (such as WarChild Holland) to give them insights into how research is used in practice. Over 4-months, the course teaches students to read social science research, to analyse it in new ways, and to write up their own views upon it for academic, public, and policy audiences.

projects.title: The Future of Care in India: Intellectual Disability in Kerala
projects.description: Who cares for people with intellectual disabilities when the state offers next to no support? Since 2019, I have been following 30 families in the city of Kozhikode in the South Indian state of Kerala as they develop solutions from within their diverse kinship groups to the challenges posed by supporting an adult family member with intellectually disabilities. Through over 10 months of immersive ethnographic fieldwork so far, I investigate how Muslim, Christian, and Hindu families of diverse socio-economic statuses find the resources, develop networks of support, and fashion new life-courses for people with intellectual disabilities in the rapidly changing context of Kerala’s diverse society, developing economy, and fragmented health and welfare provision. As the first long-term ethnographic study of intellectual disability in India, this project provides unique insights into the ways that parents attempt to create safe, valued, and meaningful futures for their children through siblings, inheritance, marriage, and new communal projects.

projects.title: Intellectual Disability and the Ethics of Care: Dependence, Freedom and Adulthood in L'Arche UK
projects.description: Why does depending on long-term care create so many obstacles for people with intellectual disabilities achieving adulthood in the UK? And how can they be overcome? In 2013-2014, I conducted 15-months of intense ethnographic research on the unusually communal care provided by the L’Arche community in the UK. This research has continued since then through publishing a wide range of articles on care, ethics, and intellectual disability - as well as through ongoing collaboration with L'Arche UK in a variety of voluntary capacities. My publications investigate the ethical difficulties of giving and receiving care, demonstrating how and why they create barriers to people with intellectual disabilities accessing adult rights, opportunities, and recognition. As the first long-term ethnographic study of a L’Arche community, it showcases how this alternative model of care reconfigures the relationship between care and intimacy within the British context to open up new ways for people with intellectual disabilities to be adults even as they remain heavily dependent on others.

projects.title: Sex and Disability in Italy
projects.description: Why do people with disabilities, on average, have fewer sexual encounters than others? Across the cities of Rome and Bologna, this research investigates pioneering projects to reshape the relationship between sex and disability in Italy that include reforming the law on sex-work, public education campaigns, and training people to become ’sexual assistants’. What happens when you try to open up sexual opportunities through the idea of ‘access’ and ‘rights’? What happens to people’s understanding of intimacy when professionals in the worlds of education, sex-therapy, and tantric massage are trained to offer these encounters?
